title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: No bull: This Austrian cow has learned to use tools
items.description: First evidence for tool use in cattle includes a skill previously seen only in humans and chimpanzees

items.title: Nearly a third of social media research has undisclosed ties to industry, preprint claims
items.description: Industry-linked studies were also more likely to focus on particular topics, suggesting these ties may be skewing the field

items.title: Purdue blocks admission of many Chinese grad students in unwritten policy
items.description: Faculty members say university is overreacting to pressure from the Trump administration and Congress

items.title: Some guest editors pack special issues with their own articles
items.description: Thousands have penned more than one-third of a journal issue, raising conflict-of-interest concerns

items.title: Did a vaporized alien planet leave behind a strange iron ‘bar’?
items.description: Astronomers puzzle over newfound feature within the picturesque Ring nebula

items.title: Illegal miners have forced Peru’s oldest environmental research station to suspend work
items.description: Staff at the Panguana biological research station have received death threats

items.title: What’s below Antarctica’s ice? New map provides clearest view yet
items.description: Technique could improve models of how ice flows, bolstering predictions of sea level rise

items.title: In fish, low doses of common pesticide speed aging and death
items.description: Polluted lakes and lab experiments highlight harms of chronic exposure to chlorpyrifos

items.title: On a Galápagos island, a ‘restoration project on steroids’
items.description: A multimillion-dollar plan aims to undo centuries of destruction on islands made famous by Darwin

items.title: Scientists turn cells’ most mysterious structures into spies on genetic activity
items.description: Enigmatic ‘vaults’ can be engineered to eavesdrop on RNA, aiding cancer studies and more
